titleStmt.title: Charles H. Phillips v. William Billings. Writ

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

bibl.title: Charles H. Phillips v. William Billings. Writ
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: In the District Court Of the Second Judicial District of Washington Territory holding terms at Olympia for the Counties of Thurston and Mason
C.H. Phillips Ex Parte Habeas Corpus
Petition
To the Honorable John P. Hoyt Judge of the Second Judicial District and Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of Washington Territory

The Petition of Charles H. Phillips respectfully shows to your Honor that he is now a prisoner, confined in the custody of William Billings Sheriff of the county of Thurston, in the county jail in the city of Olympia in said county, for a supposed criminal offense, to wit: The crime of Grand Larceny.

Your petitioner also shows that such confinement is by virtue of a pretended warrant issued, by one W.T. Keady a Justice of the Peace. That your petitioner is not im- prisoned or detained by virtue of any process issued by any court officer or tribunal upon any final judgment order or decree, nor for any contempt of any court, body, officer or tribunal, nor upon any indictment of any Grand Jury.

And your petitioner further states that he is advised by counsel, D.P. Ballard residing at Olympia, and so believes that his said imprisonment is illegal, and that said illegality consists in this, to wit: That no depositions of witnesses were taken and reduced to writing and signed by the witnesses as required by Sec 1933 Code of Washington.
No complaint was reduced to writing by the magistrate and no witnesses examined as required by law.
No case of probable cause existed or exists for charging your petitioner with said crime. And your petitioner is innocent.
No sufficient com- plaint was filed with the magistrate. No judgment has been by the magistrate as required by law. No legal warrant was issued and no valid commitment granted.
No offense has been charged against defendant as required by law.
Wherefore your petitioner prays a writ of Habeas Corpus to the end that he may be discharged from custody.
DP Ballard his attorney Charles H Billings
Territory of Washington, County of Thurston } ss

Charles H Phillips being first duly sworn, on oath says: That he is the petitioner named in teh above entitled action: that he has heard the foregoing petition read, knows the contents thereof, and believes the same to be true
Charles Phillips Subscribed and sworn to before me this 1 day of August 1884 D P Ballard Notary Public for Washington Territory.
No. 2334 Dist. Court at Olympia
Charles H Phillips Ex parte Petition for Habeas Corpus Petitioner
Received and Filed Aug 1 1884 R.G. O'Bruin Clerk
Ballard Attorneys for Petitioner
